page.title: 07Farming - Production
page.content:
Most farms in the area have a flock of breeding ewes either to graze the upland areas of their farms or to improve the quality of the grassland. The fat lambs and fleeces provide a subsidiary income. One of the biggest farms has a unit for rearing bull beef. These animals are housed on a slatted floor and fed concentrates. 150 are reared every two years. A few breeding sows are kept and the piglets sold either as weaners or fattened. The smaller farms tend to have this mixed economy.
A large amount of silage is made for winter feed; some hay is made for feeding to young stock and is also bought from the South Lancashire plain area. Average milk production from Black Moss Farm: 7200 litres per cow per lactation; 5700 litres per heifer.
